byline.original: By Jan Hoffman; Jan Hoffman, a staff writer for The Village Voice, will be a journalism fellow at Yale Law School this year

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Traveling West From Detroit about 200 miles along I-96, crack arrived in Muskegon County, Mich., late in September 1988. Or at least that's when the prosecutor Tony Tague first started noticing that a crime rampage was rocking this hard-scrabble, blue-collar county - the kind of siege that supposedly strikes only the nation's largest cities.
